learningContent.title: Adding a navtitle to a bookmap

lcInstruction.p: Occasionally, the title of a topic will lack sufficient context to be useful if it appears within a table of contents. If it is important that this topic appear within your table of contents, like a topic about a specific command in a chapter that lists several of them in sequence, use a <navtitle> element to specify a more appropriate title.
In the main body of text, the original title will appear instead of the one used in the <navtitle>

step.cmd: Inside the opening <topicref> tag that links to r_tnav.dita, add a locktitle attribute and set it to "yes" as shown:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE bookmap PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA BookMap//EN" "bookmap.dtd"> <bookmap id="ducks"> ... <topicref href="r_tnav.dita" locktitle="yes"/> ... </bookmap>

info.note: If you want the navtitle to be used in the table of contents rather than the title, you must set this attribute to "yes." Setting it to "no" or omitting it will result in the navtitle not being used.

step.cmd: Inside the <topicref> element that links to c_writing_about_ducks.dita, add a <topicmeta> element and add content to it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE bookmap PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA BookMap//EN" "bookmap.dtd"> <bookmap id="ducks"> ... <topicref href="r_tnav.dita" locktitle="yes"> <topicmeta> <navtitle>The tNav command</navtitle> </topicmeta> </topicref> ... </bookmap>

step.info: Now that you've specified a navtitle, the phrase "The tNav command" will appear in the table of contents instead of the title in that topic, which is simply "tNav."
